awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Cave Climate Histories of East/Central Asia: Deeper in Time, Wider Geographically, New Analytical Approaches, and New Tests of Climate Interpretations
awd_abstract_narration: The project builds upon the researchers' previous research piecing together a 640,000-year long, high-resolution record of the oxygen isotopic composition of cave calcite from the region of China currently affected by Asian monsoon rainfall.  The researchers aim to examine how the oxygen isotopic composition of cave calcite relates to climate using a series of tests.  These analytical tests involve (1) obtaining records from different regions of Asia, (2) obtaining extremely high resolution seasonal records of oxygen isotopic composition over specific transitions in climate, and (3) measuring the Oxygen-17 anomalies in selected cave deposits. The proposed tests of the mechanisms whereby the oxygen isotopic composition of cave calcite responds to climate aim to help illuminate the fundamental processes that cause changes in the Asian Monsoon.  This research is important because the Asian Monsoon affects millions of people and responds to regional insolation changes at orbital timescales and North Atlantic climate at millennial timescales. The project will allow the researchers to use the monsoon records as a window into high latitude climate.  The broader impacts involve supporting an early career scientist, a postdoctoral scholar, a graduate student, and fostering mutually beneficial international collaborations.

por.por_cntn:
During this project, we reconstructed historic and prehistoric climate by analyzing layers in cave deposits collected from caves across a swath of Eurasia. Over the course of this project, we expanded the geographic coverage, the coverage in terms of time, and increased the resolution of such coverage relative to previous work. We also employed additional types of analyses beyond what had been employed previously in particular cave deposits.

As a result, we have reconstructed aspects of the pattern of climate change in time and in space across Eurasia. We were able to relate these patterns to the ice age cycles, changes in the geometry of the earth's orbit and axis of rotation, and to episodes of rapid (abrupt) climate change recorded elsewhere around the world. By comparing this suite of records to each other and to the results of climate models, we were able to learn more about the phenomenon of abrupt climate change (rapid change in climate affecting much of the world and taking place in years to decades) as well as the causes of ice age terminations (the ends of ice age cycles when vast ice sheets covering much of northern North America and northern Eurasia melted). 

Beyond learning more about these particular types of climate change, this project contributed to improving the accuracy and precision of the carbon-14 dating method. Carbon-14 dates must be calibrated throughout the carbon-14 time range (the last 55,000 years). For the past 70 years, the scientific community has worked on calibrating the carbon-14 timescale. However, prior to this project, the accuracy and precision of the calibration of much of the older portion of the carbon-14 timescale was not as high as we would like. Over the course of this project, we improved the precision and accuracy of the calibration of the older portion of the timescale substantially, leading to the first reasonbly precise calibration of the full timescale.

The above constitute the main highlights of this project in terms of intellectual merit. The broader impacts of this project largely lie in the realm of furthering education. Edwards has incorporated the key findings of this project into courses ranging from introductory courses to graduate-level courses at the University of Minnesota. Edwards also advised cinematographer, Jonathan Byrd, on an IMAX film entitled ‘Ancient Caves’, which premiered in 2020 at the Science Museum of Minnesota. This film has since won awards in its format and genre for Best Film, Best Cinematography, and Best for Lifelong Learning. Finally, Edwards participated in discussions and panels in award-week activities at the Franklin Institute in April 2023. Notably, this included a participating in a panel of Benjamin Franklin Laureates discussing STEM careers with high school and middle school students.
